questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: MRgFUS causes heat necrosis in fibroid

options.label: B
options.text: HiFU can be used in those who want to preserve fertility

options.label: C
options.text: Uterine artery embolization carries a risk of femoral artery injury

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine artery embolization causes avascular necrosis of the fibroid

questions.correct_answer: B. HiFU can be used in those who want to preserve fertility
questions.explanation:
Uterine Artery Embolization (UAE)
  • Shrinks the fibroid by causing avascular necrosis (Option D)
  • Angiographic procedure in which uterine arteries are blocked using polyvinyl alcohol through the femoral artery
  • Minimally invasive
  • Risk of injury to the femoral artery (Option C)

MR-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS)
  • Focused heat to coagulate and cause necrosis in fibroid (Option A)
  • Contraindicated in:
    • Uterine size >24 weeks.
    • Myoma size >10 cm.
    • Desire for future fertility

High-Frequency Focused USG (HiFU)
  • Focused heat to coagulate and cause necrosis in fibroid
  • Cannot be used if fertility is desired (Option B)

questions.text: A 65 year old postmenopausal woman and a 35 year old premenopausal woman present with abnormal uterine bleeding. Both patients undergo transvaginal sonography (TVS), which reveals endometrial polyps. The postmenopausal woman's polyp is 2 cm in size, while the premenopausal woman's polyp is 1.7 cm and is associated with recurrent bleeding and infertility. What is the most appropriate management for each patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation and follow-up in 6 months for both patients.

options.label: C
options.text: Hysteroscopic polypectomy for the postmenopausal woman and diagnostic hysteroscopy for the premenopausal woman.

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnostic hysteroscopy for the postmenopausal woman and hysteroscopic polypectomy for the premenopausal woman.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hysteroscopic polypectomy for both patients.

questions.text: Which investigation finding can help differentiate an endometrial polyp from a fibroid?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibroids show a single feeder vessel on Doppler ultrasound.

options.label: B
options.text: Endometrial polyps have a peripheral rim of vascularity on Doppler ultrasound.

options.label: C
options.text: Hysteroscopy reveals fibroid polyps as firm and pale, endometrial polyps as soft and pink.

options.label: D
options.text: Saline infusion sonography (SIS) is not useful in here.

questions.correct_answer: C. Hysteroscopy reveals fibroid polyps as firm and pale, endometrial polyps as soft and pink.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Endometrial Polyp

Submucous fibroid

Appearance

Pink, small (1-2 cm), single or multiple, with a pedicle

Paler, firm, with broad base (sessile)/ pedunculated.

Microscopic Features

Endometrial glands and stroma, covered by columnar epithelium

Fibroids consist of spindle-shaped cells organized into interwoven bundles, creating a well-defined lesion.

Malignancy

Usually benign, can undergo secondary malignant changes

Generally benign

Common Symptoms

Menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, postmenopausal bleeding, postcoital bleeding

DIAGNOSIS

Doppler ultrasound

Typically show a single feeder vessel. (Option B)

Show a characteristic peripheral rim of vascularity with penetrating vessels. (Option A)

Hysteroscopy

Soft, smooth. reddish/pinkish mass with a slender stalk, originating from the endometrial lining.

Firm, pale mass with a broad base or stalk, from the myometrium, with prominent vessels, distorting the uterus.

Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) or sonohysterogram

Clarifies diagnoses and differentiates endometrial polyps from fibroids when TVS shows a thick or irregular endometrium.

questions.text: A 48 year old woman reports six months of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. Physical exam shows an enlarged, irregular uterus. Initial ultrasound suggests uterine fibroids, but differentiation from adenomyosis is unclear. What is the best investigation to accurately distinguish between fibroids and adenomyosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasound
  • Key Diagnostic Tool: Identifies fibroids and differentiates them from other conditions
  • Well-defined, rounded, hypoechoic (darker) appearance
  • Cystic spaces indicate degeneration
  • Vascularity: Assessed with Doppler ultrasound
  • 3D Ultrasound: Detailed size, location, and number of fibroids

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) & Sonosalpingography

Evaluate fallopian tube patency and detect submucous fibroids. (Option A)

MRI

Detailed pelvic imaging, especially for virgins, and older women, and differentiating between fibroids, adenomyosis, and sarcomas

Hysteroscopy

Diagnostic and therapeutic allows direct visualization and potential removal of submucous fibroids.

Dilation & Curettage (D&C)

Obtains endometrial tissue for biopsy in abnormal uterine bleeding, ruling out cancer in menstrual disorders or postmenopausal bleeding. (Option C)

Intravenous Pyelography (IVP)

Visualize the urinary tract when a broad ligament fibroid is suspected to check for ureter compression

Laparoscopy
  • Confirm diagnosis when other methods are inconclusive (Option D)
  • Investigate associated conditions like PID or endometriosis
  • Assist in procedures to prevent uterine perforation

questions.text: A 35 year old woman with a history of early menarche, nulliparity, and a maternal history of uterine fibroids presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and occasional pelvic pain. A pelvic ultrasound confirms uterine fibroid polyps. Which factor in her history is most strongly associated with her increased risk of developing uterine fibroid polyps?
questions.explanation:
Endometrial Polyp

Uterine Fibroid
  • Menstrual Disturbances: menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, intermenstrual bleeding, postmenopausal bleeding
  • Postcoital Bleeding (if the polyp protrudes through the cervical canal)
  • Asymptomatic in some cases.
  • Menstrual Disturbances: Similar to endometrial polyps with heavy and irregular bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Infertility and pregnancy loss (with Submucous fibroid polyps)
  • Vaginal Discharge (with pedunculated submucous fibroids)
  • Asymptomatic (often an incidental finding)

questions.text: A 36 year old woman undergoes an operative hysteroscopy. What early complication can be expected after this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Early complications

Distention media related:

  • Fluid overload (Option A)
  • Hyponatremia
  • Gas embolism
  • Glycine toxicity

Operative:

  • Uterine perforation
  • Hemorrhage
  • Thermal burns
  • Infection

Late complications
  • Scar rupture in the next pregnancy (Option C)
  • Uterine adhesions (Option D)
  • Hematoma (Option B)
  • Post-ablation sterilization syndrome

questions.text: A 35 year old woman has been diagnosed with a submucosal fibroid. She is considered for a hysteroscopic myomectomy. Bipolar electrosurgical loop is used during her procedure. Which of the following findings made her a suitable candidate for hysteroscopic myomectomy and what distention fluid was used?
A 34 year old lady is concerned about her upcoming myomectomy operation. Which of the following is not a complication of this operation?
Which of the following is NOT used to minimize blood loss in myomectomy?

A 32 year old woman has been trying to conceive for 2 years. She is diagnosed with uterine fibroid. She is interested in having a myomectomy. What tests should be performed before confirming the procedure?

A 38 year old nulliparous woman came with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and recurrent pregnancy loss. She desires to get pregnant. On USG, submucosal fibroid is seen. Which of the following is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.explanation:
Hysteroscopy

Laparoscopy

Indication
  • Fibroid of 3–4 cm in diameter
  • Type 0 submucosal
  • Type 1 submucosal
  • Subserous
  • Intramural fibroids
  • Type 2 submucosal

Instrument used
  • Electrocautery
  • Electro-diathermy
  • Harmonics
  • Laser
  • Extracorporeal sutures

questions.text: A 38 year old nulliparous woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and painful menstrual cramps. Ultrasound confirms the presence of multiple uterine fibroids. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic factor contributing to the development of her fibroids?
questions.explanation:
Fibroids

Risk factors

Protective Factors
  • Increasing age >50 (80%).
  • Hyperestrogenic state: Early menarche, Nulliparity, Obesity, ↑ body mass index (BMI).
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
  • Black women.
  • High-fat diet, Red meat.
  • Family history.
  • Late menarche.
  • Multiparity. (Option B)
  • Early Menopause. (Option A)
  • Combined oral contraceptives (COC).
  • Smoking. (Option D)

questions.text: A 39 year old woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic discomfort. Pelvic examination reveals a palpable irregular mass consistent with fibroids, and USG reveals distortion of the uterine cavity. She wishes to avoid surgery and seeks medical management. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Features

NSAIDs (Option A)
  • Reduces pain, not the bleeding

Tranexamic acid (Option B)
  • Antifibrinolytic agent
  • Reduces bleeding, not the pain

GnRH analogues- Leuprorelin, Goserelin
  • Suppresses estrogen and progesterone levels after the initial flare of symptoms due to increased estrogen and progesterone
  • Decreases fibroid size and vascularity
  • Also used before myomectomy to reduce blood loss

GnRH antagonist- cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Directly decreases estrogen and progesterone levels
  • Decreases fibroid size and vascularity

Mifepristone
  • Antagonises progesterone receptor in fibroid
  • Reduces bleeding

Ulipristal (Option C)
  • Selective Progesterone receptor modulator
  • Reduces the size of fibroid by antagonising progesterone receptors

Mirena (LNG IUD) (Option D)
  • Reduces blood loss
  • Not recommended when the uterus is> 12 weeks in size, or there is a distortion of the cavity.

questions.text: A 48 year old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and a sensation of pelvic fullness. Her menstrual cycles have become increasingly irregular over the past year. A pelvic USG confirms the presence of uterine leiomyomas. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment given to the patient?

A 42 year old woman reports chronic pelvic pain, heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, and lower abdominal fullness. Her pelvic exam shows an enlarged, irregular uterus. Which imaging modality best assesses the number, size, and location of uterine fibroids?

A 38 year old woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and frequent urination. On physical examination, her uterus is found to be irregularly enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the recommended treatment for red degeneration of fibroids in pregnant women?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate myomectomy to remove the fibroid

options.label: C
options.text: Conservative management with pain relief and supportive care

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of high-dose steroids to reduce inflammation and then surgical removal

questions.correct_answer: C. Conservative management with pain relief and supportive care

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents to the ER with sudden-onset severe lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the lower abdomen. Pelvic USG reveals a large heterogeneous mass in the myometrium with areas of necrosis and irregular margins. What is the most likely condition from the options given below?
questions.explanation:
Type of degeneration

Pathophysiology

Hyaline degeneration

Accumulation of proteinous tissue

Cystic degeneration

Extreme fluid collection

Calcareous degeneration (womb stone)

Deposition of phosphates and carbonates in the periphery

Red degeneration (hemorrhagic)

Decrease in blood supply to the fibroid

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain and irregular menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. On examination, a pelvic mass is palpable on the right side, confirmed to be a true broad ligament fibroid on imaging. Which of the following statements is not true regarding primary broad ligament fibroid?

options.label: A
options.text: They arise from the broad ligament

options.label: B
options.text: Uterine vessels and ureter lie medial to the fibroid

options.label: C
options.text: Uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to the fibroid

questions.correct_answer: C. Uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to the fibroid
questions.explanation:
True/primary broad ligament fibroid

Pseudo/secondary broad ligament fibroid

Rare condition directly arising from the broad ligament (Option A&D)

More common condition that arises from the uterus but grows laterally.

Uterine vessels and ureter lies medial to the tumour (Option B)

Uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to the tumour (Option C)

Manifests as extrauterine pelvic mass and may compress the ureter, urethra, bladder and bowel causing bowel and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: Identify the location of the fibroid marked C in the diagram.
questions.explanation:
FIGO Classification of Fibroids.
 

Type

Name

Submucosal

0

Pedunculated, Intracavity

1

<50% Intramural and rest in cavity

2

≥ 50% Intramural and a part in cavity

3

100% intramural but contacts endometrium

Intramural

4

Intramural

Subserosal

5

≥ 50% Intramural and partly in serosa

6

<50% Intramural and rest in serosa

7

Subserosal Pedunculated

Others

8

Other - Cervical, Parasitic

2-5

Hybrid - Present both in the cavity (type 2) and in the serosa (type 5)

questions.text: The 45-year-old multiparous woman underwent a hysterectomy for abnormal uterine bleeding after failed medical management. The uterus is firm and irregularly enlarged with multiple tumours in the myometrium with a characteristic whorled appearance on cut-section. HPE shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
